sect3.para: Although gene-based comparisons are emerging as an important strategy for strain typing and for characterizing bacteria and other pathogens using WGS data, current limitations with short-read NGS and bioinformatics analysis may impact their usefulness, particularly for large-scale comparisons. The reliance of these techniques on high-quality genomic assemblies and the consistent prediction or annotation of open reading frames presents challenges in terms of the technical complexity and throughput of the analysis. Draft bacterial genomes may include hundreds of contigs, and the interpretation of complex MLST schemes will invariably be affected by breaks, duplications, or misassemblies of important sequences or reading frames. Differences in assembly or gene prediction algorithms may also impact the throughput of the assay and interpretation of results, and the development of standardized bioinformatics methods and workflows is critical, particularly as sequence databases scale to hundreds or thousands of genomes with many different alleles.

figure.title: FIGURE 4 Heat map showing the SNPs among 10 STEC O157 isolates belonging to the same outbreak. In order to elucidate the genetic relationships among the outbreak isolates, high-quality SNPs were called against the outbreak reference strain (index case), which appears at the far left. A total of nine SNPs were detected among the outbreak isolates. The nine outbreak isolates (2091 through 2098) differ from the index case (Ref_2090) at all nine SNP loci, but share all alleles among themselves. In this case, the putative index case is likely an inappropriate choice of reference, unless an outgroup is needed.

sect3.para: Gene-based microbial subtyping schemes can target varying number of genes from dozens (ribosomal MLST) to hundreds (expanded MLST) to thousands (core genome MLST [cgMLST] and whole-genome MLST [wgMLST]). The two subtyping schemes with the highest resolution are cgMLST, in which genes present in the vast majority of all strains of a given species are included, and wgMLST, in which all or nearly all genes (core and accessory genes, also known as the pangenome) present in a given species are included. While wgMLST provides the higher resolution that is required for short-term outbreak investigations, cgMLST provides long-term stability, which is desirable if strain type nomenclature is to be implemented. In addition to strain typing information, the presence or absence of specific genes or genetic variants may also be important and useful information for microbial characterization, particularly when used in conjunction with other strain typing methods. Interrogating sets of known resistance and virulence markers can provide important information during an outbreak investigation or response, and these features can often be used to support strain type identification and the prediction of phenotypic properties (e.g., antimicrobial resistance) (117) or to correlate with transmission dynamics and patient outcomes.

sect3.title: k-mer-Based Analyses
sect3.para: k-mer-based algorithms have quickly emerged as an important approach to assemble, analyze, and compare large genomic datasets in a computationally efficient manner. In general, these algorithms deconstruct longer genomic sequences or unassembled raw reads into large sets of k-mers, or oligonucleotides of length “k,” for comparison by means of suffix arrays (118). The k-mers can then be quickly counted, sorted, deduplicated, and compared to other k-mer sequence sets to identify variations (SNPs and indels) that can be used for clustering and comparison (119). Often, k-mer-based algorithms are an intrinsic first step in downstream sequence analysis or assembly workflows. For example, the SPADes assembler uses multiple rounds of k-mer analyses in order to select and optimize assembly parameters (120). Sequence repositories, such as the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI), have also implemented k-mer-based methods for categorization, characterization, and quality control of submitted sequences. As an example, the NCBI’s Pathogen Detection Project (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pathogens) uses k-mer-based approaches and other analyses to compare and visualize submitted sequence data in near-real time for organisms that have less than 1,000 isolates in the repository. k-mer-based methods can be used to assess horizontal gene transfer, annotate SNP positions based on a known reference, and earmark missing alleles and evidence of evolutionary convergence, and they are easily adapted to new applications, such as the metagenomic analysis of complex samples (119, 121). During outbreak investigations, k-mer-based sequence analysis is an excellent tool for initial comparison and clustering of genomes because it provides actionable strain typing information quickly and can be used to select appropriate reference strains for SNP typing, assess the overall quality of sequence data, and guide the application of more resource-intensive downstream bioinformatics analyses, which may take much longer to complete.

While k-mer trees are often used in conjunction with SNP-based phylogenies, it is important to understand that the two are not functionally equivalent and that there are important tradeoffs for the speed advantages of k-mer-based analyses. Unlike traditional SNP-mapping approaches, which take into consideration the genomic context of the variant position and the underlying sequence quality of the reads that support its identification, k-mer-based SNP analysis focuses on the putative SNP position and the 10 to 12 bases of surrounding sequence, without considering quality scores. These are important limitations which may restrict the ability of k-mer-based methods to reliably detect closely spaced SNPs or indels and may result in limited resilience against low sequence quality or sequencing errors. Even so, k-mer methods have significant advantages in terms of speed and implementation, since they do not require assembly or alignment of sequences and can be equally applied to whole-genome sequence sets and unassembled sets of short reads.

sect2.title: DNA Microarrays
sect2.para: A DNA microarray is a molecular platform in which a few hundred to thousands of specific DNA oligonucleotides or short sequences (capture molecules) are bound to a matrix. The array is used to detect specific DNA sequences (target sequences) in a test sample of fluorescently labeled DNA, with or without amplification, by hybridization followed by detection of the array-bound test DNA.

Until relatively recently, DNA microarrays were a compelling, albeit expensive, platform for comprehensive microbial identification and characterization. While DNA microarrays allow the simultaneous interrogation of hundreds of thousands of targets within a given sample, the technology is expensive and rigid and does not scale well for many public health applications. Per-sample cost, sample throughput, and turnaround time are all critical bottlenecks, and even with access to dedicated microarray printing facilities, altering or adjusting the composition or layout of microarrays to meet changing requirements is not trivial. Reproducibility is also an important consideration, since ambiguities in the interpretation of the ratios of hybridization and cross-hybridization to analogous targets are of concern. Despite the availability of bioinformatics tools and standards to compare microarray data (122), interlaboratory reproducibility studies are largely absent from the literature (123).

While the use of microarrays themselves is on the decline, a recent trend has seen the adaptation of established amplicon microarray probe sets to newer, more flexible and cost-effective technology platforms, such as NGS amplicon sequencing, multiplex CRISPR panels, or digital droplet PCR. In many cases, primers and probe sets have already undergone extensive validation during array development and can be easily adapted to massively parallel amplicon sequencing approaches, such as Ion Torrent AmpliSeq (ThermoFisher, South San Francisco, CA) or Fluidigm Juno (Fluidigm, South San Francisco, CA). While these technologies cannot approach the same target density as a planar microarray, at least not at present, they are significantly more flexible and scalable, and they deliver sequence data for hundreds or thousands of targets, which is a clear advantage over qualitative hybridization.

sect2.title: Mass Spectrometry
sect2.para: In recent years, matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time-of-flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) systems have become increasingly common in clinical and public health microbiology laboratories throughout the world. In contrast to earlier generations of MS equipment, which were complex, costly, and difficult to maintain, these newer low-profile and benchtop MALDI-TOF MS systems offer simple and standardized workflows for many genus- and species-level microbial identification tasks, with high throughput, accurate and fast results, and a low overall cost per test (124). While proof-of-concept studies have repeatedly demonstrated the feasibility of MALDI-TOF MS for strain- and subspecies-level identification of select organisms (125–127), standardized or generalizable methods have yet to be developed, and in most cases, the current level of resolution of MALDI-TOF MS, when used alone, remains at the genus or species level. Attempts have been made by some commercial companies to combine MS with other technologies and typing approaches. The Agilent MassCode (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) uses highly multiplexed PCR panels and identifies and subtypes microorganisms through the detection and measurement of cleavable mass tags using atmospheric pressure chemical ionization, quadrupole MS (128). Other platforms, such as the Sequenom MassARRAY (Agena Bioscience, San Diego, CA), use PCR MALDI-TOF MS to interrogate thousands of SNPs through single-primer base extension and can be used for high-resolution SNP-based strain typing using standardized sets of canonical targets (129). However, these applications remain under active development and in most cases do not currently provide the discriminatory power needed for epidemiologically relevant high-resolution strain typing.

sect2.title: APPLICATIONS
sect2.para: Applications of molecular epidemiology cover a wide and expanding gamut, ranging from local public health investigations and applied research, to national and international surveillance and monitoring for pathogens of public health and economic concern. The scale of the application, the intended use, objectives and applicability of the data, and many other factors may influence the choice of laboratory methods, sampling strategy, and performance factors.

At a local level, molecular and genomic epidemiology is often used for outbreak and cluster investigations, to understand patterns and routes of transmission and guide infection control and public health resources; to monitor environmental, wastewater, and animal sources for important pathogens or transmission risks; to protect vulnerable settings and populations and to better understand the factors leading to severe or unusual illness; and to rapidly detect emerging infectious diseases before they spread. Molecular platforms, including pathogen genomic sequencing, are becoming increasingly portable, and a number of recent studies have demonstrated the feasibility of real-time, point-of-need genomic epidemiology for Zika, Ebola, influenza, and a host of other pathogens of public health concern (130, 131).

At a national and international level, molecular epidemiology is a critically important tool to monitor large-scale trends in pathogen diversity and evolution over time; to understand transmission dynamics at a local, regional, and national level; to understand the impact of therapeutic and nontherapeutic interventions in controlling and preventing disease; and to better inform public health responses, including contact tracing and other mitigation strategies. Ongoing surveillance can help establish baselines for monitoring and guide surveillance strategy. When paired with strong local public health capacity, large-scale molecular surveillance efforts can also help to detect the emergence of clinically important pathogens at a national or international scale; to understand cases with unusual virulence or phenotypic presentation; to better anticipate the disruption of diagnostic, antigenic, or therapeutic targets; and to guide and inform more effective public health policy to safeguard the health of the population.
The following section includes examples of how molecular epidemiology is used in practice.

sect2.title: Molecular Genotyping
sect2.para: Serotyping is a subtyping method in which specific antigens on the surface of microorganisms are detected by antigen-antibody reactions using diagnostic antisera. The method is definitive but only moderately discriminatory. It has nevertheless proven to be extremely useful for epidemiologic classification of a number of pathogens and has for this reason been a mainstay in the surveillance of different infectious diseases for more than 70 years. It is a cumbersome method that requires the availability of high-quality antisera and substantial expertise to perform the assay and interpret the results. More convenient, rapid, and reliable molecular alternatives to serotyping are being developed. These molecular serotyping methods are designed to generate data that are in close or complete agreement with conventional serotyping, in order to not lose the connection to the historical data and to provide the ability to roughly compare results between laboratories, regardless of their progress on transition to routine genomic sequencing. Molecular flagellin typing ofCampylobacter (flaA typing), M serotyping (emm typing) of GAS, and capsular (cps) typing of pneumococci are discussed above.

In the genusSalmonella, more than 2,500 serotypes are currently recognized (132). With the advent of WGS, serotype information can be extracted from the sequence data. One primary method to determine serotype from WGS data is by extracting the sequence data from an isolate for the genes encoding the serotype. In this case, the genes for the O antigens are within the rfb gene cluster, and for the H antigens, the flagellar genes fliC and fliB, which encode the phase 1 and phase 2 antigens, respectively, are extracted. This method is directly compatible with the Kauffman-White scheme, which contains all phenotypic descriptions of all Salmonella serotypes (133). An example of software that performs this function is SeqSero2 (134). Another tool, called SISTR, uses a cgMLST approach that includes MLST and rMLST targets to define serotypes from WGS data, though this method is not directly compatible with the Kauffman-White scheme. Some other examples of subtyping methods that correlate with serotyping are MLST, PFGE, ribotyping, and rep-PCR (135); the correlation between subtyping methods is never perfect, and ideally, serotypes determined this way should be confirmed by traditional serotyping or a sequence-based serotyping method targeting the serotype-encoding genes (132, 133, 136, 137).

sect2.title: Genotyping of Viruses
sect2.para: Cross-neutralization and serologic typing of viruses preceded the routine use of molecular methods by several decades; once it was established that group relatedness of virus preparations could be reliably ascertained by differences in antigenicity, serologic testing became an important standard for typing (138, 139). While serologic testing is still an essential component of viral characterization, sequence-based molecular epidemiologic approaches are now much more widely used to study viral relatedness and to infer patterns of transmission. The most common approach is to perform sequence analysis on a defined region of the viral genome that contains sufficient diversity from which to produce valid group typing from genetic analyses. Regions and length of these “genotyping windows” vary with each viral species and genotype. Typical genotyping windows include capsid proteins, noncoding hypervariable regions, or any other region offering sufficient group resolution by phylogenetic inference. For many virus groups, new genotypic assignments are designed to allow maximum agreement with serotyping. This is often achieved by sequencing the gene coding for capsid or surface glycoproteins, because these proteins are more antigenic. Another advantage of the use of the capsid region for some viruses is that it is less prone to recombination. For example, the picornavirus VP1 subunit is used for determining over 100 enterovirus types (140) because the non-capsid-coding region frequently recombines. Hypervariable regions are also useful in typing certain viruses; for example, the M-F intergenic region of measles virus contains considerable intra-genotype diversity; the region is increasingly used to augment phylogenetic resolution alongside sequencing windows in the hemagglutinin (H) and nucleoprotein (N) genes (141). Increasingly, whole-genome methods are preferred.

Many viruses are conventionally typed by the genotyping window. For taxonomic purposes, viruses are formally classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV) into family, genus, species, and type. For the purpose of molecular epidemiology, viruses can further be distinguished (informally) into clades, genogroups, or clusters by comparison with established reference strains. In particular, RNA viruses have high mutation rates, which increase the amount of sequence variation in the genome (142, 143).

Linking viral genotypes to disease is an important application in clinical microbiology. Even within the same viral species, certain genotypes are more pathogenic than the others. For example, there are over 100 types of human papillomavirus, but only 15 are classified as high-risk types (types16, 18, 31, 33, 35, 39, 45, 51, 52, 56, 58, 59, 68, 73, and 82) (143). There are over 100 types of enteroviruses (Picornaviridae), but the range of diseases includes acute flaccid paralysis, aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, neonatal sepsis-like illness, and rash illness, as well as respiratory and enteric diseases. From a clinical perspective, distinguishing between low- and high-risk genotypes, and the diseases associated with the different types, provides important information for intervention. Genotyping of viral species is a crucial part of investigations into the emergence, evolution, and transmission of disease.

sect2.title: Vaccination Monitoring
sect2.para: Live attenuated vaccines are used to control a number of viral diseases. In some cases, these vaccines can cause symptoms that are similar to those caused by infection with wild-type virus. When the risk of exposure to disease is very low, these vaccine reactions can be identified by temporal association with vaccination. However, when vaccination is used as part of an outbreak response, it may be difficult to distinguish vaccine reactions from symptoms caused by the wild-type virus. Since serologic techniques usually lack the sensitivity to distinguish between antibodies directed at the vaccine or the wild-type strain, genetic characterization of the viruses is usually the only means available to clearly classify the case as vaccine associated or due to a wild-type infection. Of course, this approach requires that appropriate specimens for virologic detection be collected from the suspected cases and that sequence information be available for the vaccine strains.

The availability of molecular methods that can clearly identify vaccine reactions, as described above, has contributed to our knowledge about the safety of live attenuated vaccines. In addition, molecular techniques now play an important role in the post-licensure evaluation of live attenuated viral vaccines. Here, genetic characterization is used to monitor the stability of vaccines in the field and to clearly identify vaccine reactions. In one example, PCR and RFLP analyses were used to monitor the safety of varicella-zoster vaccine by classifying vesicular rash or zoster cases as being associated with wild-type varicella-zoster virus or the Oka vaccine strain (144). Additionally, some viruses have the capacity to recombine or reassort their genomes, and in these cases, WGS is an important component of molecular epidemiologic studies. The live attenuated strains used in the WHO polio eradication program replicate in the human gut and can be excreted for several weeks after immunization. If the attenuating mutations in the vaccine strains revert, the vaccine may cause vaccine-associated paralytic poliomyelitis in vaccinees or result in transmissible, neurovirulent, circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus strains, which have been associated with outbreaks of poliomyelitis (145, 146). The vaccine-derived polioviruses often contain mosaic genomes that result from recombination between the vaccine strains and other lineages of poliovirus or other enteroviruses (146), and these variants can be detected only by full-genome sequencing. Rapid detection of measles vaccine reactions that occur during an outbreak response is essential to avoid unnecessary public health interventions. The standard method to identify measles vaccine strains was Sanger sequencing, but more recently, a vaccine-specific RT-PCR assay was developed to identify vaccine reactions in less than 3 hours (147, 148).

In some cases, data from ongoing molecular surveillance of viral and bacterial pathogens are used to decide on the most appropriate formulation for vaccines, and to assess for ongoing vaccine safety and effectiveness. The geographic distribution of strains may affect the efficacy of the vaccines, especially if genetic changes in the pathogen affect antigenicity, replication, or the kinetics of receptor binding. Therefore, for pathogens with highly variable antigenic profiles (e.g., rotavirus and influenza virus), careful monitoring of the strains associated with cases in vaccinated populations is necessary (149, 150). For example, over 120 WHO Member States take part in the Global Influenza Surveillance and Response System (GISRS), combining data from ongoing global monitoring of the virological, clinical, genomic, and epidemiological properties of circulating viruses to determine the composition of seasonal influenza vaccines (151). Laboratory surveillance for vaccine-preventable viruses and bacteria is critical information that helps maintain effective vaccine strategy and immunization practices, helps tailor vaccine formulation and composition, and helps to assess the risk of antigenic escape.

sect1.title: Cluster Detection and Outbreak Investigations
sect1.para: Subtyping methods that are used for community-wide routine surveillance to detect disease case clusters and to support outbreak investigations need to be rapid, highly discriminatory, reproducible, and amenable to library subtyping, so that trends in the occurrence of the organisms they target may be followed easily. Often, subtyping results are the only information available to determine if an outbreak investigation should be initiated. In this situation, the case definition needs to be very specific (i.e., the discriminatory power of the subtyping method needs to be high) in order not to include patients that are not associated with the outbreak as cases, which would confuse the epidemiological investigation. The molecular methods that are most suitable for this purpose are PFGE, MLVA, and highly discriminatory DNA arrays, many of which are currently being replaced by WGS. These methods may be used in conjunction with less discriminatory traditional and molecular methods (e.g., biotyping, serotyping, phage typing, antibiograms, and/or plasmid profiling).

PulseNet, the national molecular subtyping network for foodborne-disease surveillance, is a prime example of a network performing real-time surveillance of infectious diseases at the community level (152). In a subtyping network, the choice of method is less important than is the requirement that all participants use the same method, as long as the preferred method has sufficient performance characteristics. For PulseNet, the preferred subtyping method was PFGE for over 20 years, until it was eventually replaced in all laboratories by WGS-based methods (112). Compared to PFGE, WGS has superior sensitivity and specificity, enabling more efficient outbreak detection and investigation by better distinguishing outbreak cases from sporadic cases (153). For example, for listeriosis, the number of outbreaks detected in the first 2 years following implementation of WGS in the United States in 2013 increased markedly, and the number of outbreaks that were linked to a contaminated food product increased by more than 100% (105).

The requirements for methods used for surveillance and investigation of outbreaks in hospitals and other institutions may be different from the ones used in the community. The setting is much smaller in scale and usually attended by a single laboratory, and the outbreaks are often caused by pathogens transmitted from person to person and/or by pathogens that persist in the environment. Strains that are involved in outbreaks transmitted between patients or persistently from the environment often evolve during the outbreak, and variant subtypes may be present at the same time. The methods that are used for community-wide surveillance may also be used for these health care-related outbreaks, and methods that do not show good interlaboratory reproducibility may be used as long as the intralaboratory reproducibility is sufficient. PCR-based methods are cost-efficient for short-term surveillance and to delineate outbreaks that have been detected by phenotypic or other less discriminatory methods (154–156), but will likely be replaced by WGS in the near future.

The combination of molecular epidemiologic techniques and standard case classification and reporting provides a very sensitive means to investigate transmission. A prime example involves tuberculosis (TB) transmission. Genotyping ofMycobacterium tuberculosis complex strains by PCR-based methods like Mycobacterial Interspersed Repetitive Units (MIRU)-VNTR has been used for decades to help identify persons with TB disease involved in the same chain of recent transmission (157). Given that TB disease can manifest several months to years after TB infection, molecular epidemiology can help outbreak investigations by identifying recently or newly acquired TB infection. In recent years, adoption of WGS for TB genotyping has increased resolution for strain classification and enhanced the ability of public health investigators to distinguish TB cases associated with recent transmission from reactivation and sporadic cases (158) (https://www.cdc.gov/tb/programs/genotyping/default.htm).

Additionally, molecular epidemiologic techniques can substantiate the transmission pathways of many viruses. In particular, analysis of the sequence data can help substantiate epidemiologic links between outbreak cases, as well as confirm the source of a virus or suggest a source for cases in which the source was unknown. Transmission can occur in many contexts for highly infectious viruses such as measles virus; source attribution of outbreak cases may depend upon such variables as geography, temporality, vaccination status, or travel history (159). Molecular techniques have been used to identify the source of the infections when standard case investigations have failed to identify a source (160). Molecular tests used in outbreak investigations vary for different viruses. Important factors include specificity, sensitivity, reproducibility, turnaround time, cost, and ease of execution. Turnaround time is crucial in the rapid response to an outbreak. Many standard methods involve pathogen isolation, which is time-intensive. By contrast, direct detection from clinical samples, by PCR/RT-PCR followed by Sanger sequencing, has significantly expedited the practice of outbreak investigation; application of new NGS techniques has further provided significant improvements. Direct detection of pathogens from clinical specimens by NGS is increasingly evaluated for sensitivity and turnaround time, having proven useful in recent scale-ups of SARS-CoV-2 sequencing and other specific cases (161, 162).

Hospitals and public health laboratories are at the front lines during outbreaks, and many of these institutions now have syndromic surveillance capability using a multiplex system that detects a panel of disease-specific pathogens. Some examples are FilmArray (BioFire, bioMérieux, Marcy l’Etoile, France), xTAG (Luminex, Austin, TX), and the TaqMan array card (ThermoFisher, Waltham, MA). Currently, these syndromic testing systems can determine only the presence of a pathogen, not the specific genotype. While microbial genomic sequencing is not always the most practical option for public health or hospital infection control teams responding to outbreaks, these approaches are increasingly used in tandem with syndromic surveillance and lower-cost screening and surveillance assays, and have proven invaluable for enhanced active surveillance for emerging pathogens and resistance, outbreak investigations, and response (153, 163).

sect2.title: Source Attribution
sect2.para: Source attribution is the epidemiological science that studies the relative contribution of different sources to the burden of infectious diseases. Strictly speaking, outbreak investigations are source attribution analyses, but the term is more commonly used in a broader sense, encompassing both outbreak-related and sporadic disease. Molecular methods may be used to study the geographic distribution or sources and spread of microbial strains, and this is discussed below.

Source attribution using microbiological methods is gaining increasing attention, especially in the study of foodborne disease, where it is used to estimate where in the food production chain the largest public health problems originate. Decision makers use these estimates to prioritize where control efforts can be spent most efficiently. A subtyping method that is used for source attribution creates subtypes that are distributed unevenly between the different possible sources of human infection. When this knowledge is combined with information about the distribution of the same subtypes in sick humans and, if available, the rates of human exposure to each source, it is possible to estimate the relative contribution of each source to the burden of human disease (164). This approach was introduced in the United Kingdom to identify the sources of Campylobacter jejuni and Campylobacter coli as predominantly chicken meat, with ruminants being another important source (165), and has since been used in many countries to identify the sources of campylobacteriosis and to demonstrate the effect of intervention measures (166).

The limitation of the model is that it identifies only sources for which there are data available (i.e., if no isolates are included from a potential major source, no estimates for this source will be generated). Subtyping methods used for source attribution do not need to be as discriminatory or reproducible as those used for outbreak investigations, as long as they clearly differentiate isolates from different sources. Choosing a subtyping method with an unnecessarily high discriminatory power will increase the complexity of the analysis of the data set. In regard toCampylobacter, housekeeping gene MLST works well for attribution. A number of source attribution projects using WGS have been completed as well (167). In a study of zoonotic source attribution of S. enterica serotype Typhimurium using a global phylogeny, major livestock sources for these strains were predicted in the United States (168). Other groups have used core genome multilocus sequence typing to attribute the source of human illness due to C. jejuni and C. coli (169). As databases containing sequence data from clinical cases and sources grow, the ability to attribute illness to a likely source will also improve.

sect2.title: Forensic Microbiology
sect2.para: Sometimes infectious disease incidents are criminally investigated if there is a suspicion that they may be the result of deliberate actions or criminal gross negligence. HIV-infected individuals have been imprisoned for spreading the virus intentionally (170) or through negligence (171), and anthrax has been spread through the mail (55, 172). Numerous outbreaks of foodborne infections occur each year, and some have been the result of intentional contamination of the food supply (173). Forensic molecular epidemiology comes into play when regulators and laymen, judges, and lawyers have to decide if an infection (or infections) is a result of criminal action. In principle, criminal microbiological investigations are not different from outbreak investigations, except that in criminal investigations, the link between the infection(s) and its source(s) needs to be proven beyond reasonable doubt. In outbreak investigations, the precautionary principle is often used when deciding on public health actions, since the aim of an outbreak investigation is to stop the outbreak from spreading as soon as possible. This is often in contrast to criminal investigations, where precautionary principle is not used, since an offender is presumed innocent until proven otherwise. Subtyping methods that may quantify the probability that two microbial strains are related are therefore preferred over methods that do not yield direct quantifiable information. Non-target-specific methods are therefore not ideal for criminal investigations, because DNA fragments of the same size may have completely different sequence content. For example, it is not possible to tell from the PFGE pattern if two isolates are identical; hence the use of the term “indistinguishable” for PFGE patterns that cannot be differentiated from each other. In contrast, differences observed with a target-specific method may be quantifiable if the prevalence of the detected alleles is known in the relevant microbial populations.

WGS-based methods have greatly improved the ability of investigators to detect evidence of genetic engineering or manipulation (174). In most microbial forensic investigations, however, the primary focus is on establishing scientific evidence for civil or criminal liability, such as health care-associated or foodborne outbreaks that were exacerbated by provider negligence, clusters of hepatitis C associated with pharmaceutical diversion, or widespread infections caused by contaminated pharmaceuticals or medical products (175, 176).

sect2.title: Pathogen Evolution
sect2.para: Molecular techniques have made enormous contributions to our understanding of pathogen evolution by comparative sequence analysis; however, detailed descriptions of these studies are beyond the scope of this chapter. Traditional comparative statistics, such as thedS/dN ratio (the ratio of the number of synonymous substitutions per synonymous site to the number of nonsynonymous substitutions per nonsynonymous site), allow the estimation of evolutionary pressures on a pathogen genome. Phylogenetic methods in particular are used to monitor diversity of circulating pathogens across variables of interest, to monitor the stability of antigenic sites defining diagnostic and vaccine targets, and to assess susceptibility to antimicrobial drugs.

Software implementations of maximum likelihood and Bayesian phylogenetic methods are under continuous development, offering improvements in runtime efficiency and model flexibility (177–179). Bayesian methods, such as those provided by BEAST (Bayesian Evolutionary Analysis and Sampling Trees) (180), incorporate sample metadata and permit inference of the evolutionary dynamics from sequence data. Bayesian phylodynamic approaches may attempt inference of base substitution rates, change of pathogen population size, and geographic diffusion processes, among others (181). Analysis of hepatitis C virus sequences from Egypt suggested an exponential increase in the number of cases starting in 1930 and then again in 1955 (182), when unsterile needles began to be widely distributed for an anti-schistosomal therapy. Similar studies documented the episodic transmission of HIV in London during the late 1990s (183). With these approaches, sequence information from infectious agents can be used to infer the transmission patterns of that agent over time and space; increasingly, sequence-based models have also been used to infer conventional epidemiologic parameters (184).

Investigations of sequence evolution by Bayesian or related methods may test complex evolutionary hypotheses that extend beyond genetic relatedness of pathogens; however, the techniques are computationally expensive and require specialized expertise in model selection. Efficient use of these techniques is typically not accessible in environments without access to research-grade computational infrastructure. The greatest utility of these methods is realized for retrospective studies for which panels of sequence data are of sufficient inter-strain diversity to resolve posterior estimates of mathematical parameters controlling the evolution of the dataset. As with all modeled evolutionary systems, the utility of phylogenetic methods is limited by the availability of accurate biochemical (e.g., base substitution mechanisms) or epidemiologic (e.g., reproductive rate) assumptions. Likewise, the viability of modeled inference may be influenced by unknown selection pressures or by inherent biases toward disease severity in the sampled population.

Advances in acquisition of sequence content, usually WGS by NGS methods, offer improved resolution of substitution mechanisms and consequent identification of strain emergence mechanisms. Surveillance of measles virus represents an uncomplicated case for which extended or WGS sequencing windows may offer increased resolution for comparative analyses of localized, genetically homogenous outbreaks (185, 186). Genetic drift (accumulation of mutations over time) and genetic shift (recombination and reassortment) are mechanisms of pathogen evolution which may be misclassified when incomplete sequencing windows are used. Complex reassortment events may indeed punctuate the evolution of human viruses with segmented genomes (influenza virus, rotavirus/reovirus, bunyaviruses, and arenaviruses) (187, 188). Reconstruction of reassortment events is an informative epidemiologic tool, having been used to resolve the genetic emergence of the 1918 H1N1, 1957 H2N2, 1968 H3N2, and 2009 H1N1 influenza pandemics.

sect2.title: Geographic Spread
sect2.para: If a sequence dataset contains sufficient geographic structure, the information can be used to monitor spatial epidemiology of the pathogen. The sensitivity of these approaches depends on both the geographic breadth of surveillance activity and the availability of genetic information covering the epidemiologic event in question. Notably, geographically informed sequence analysis was used to identify the source of West Nile virus in the United States following introduction in 1999, and to reconstruct spatial diffusion of the virus by counterintuitive, irregular transmission events (189, 190). Likewise, genetic diversity using these methods has been used to track the global spread of HIV variants (191).

Sequence analysis has also been used to characterize the emergence and track the spread ofCandida auris, a multidrug-resistant fungal pathogen causing severe invasive disease that, in the past decade, has emerged in health care settings worldwide (192). C. auris has a strong phylogeographic structure whereby isolates from cases generally cluster by geography into one of five major clades or subtypes (193). These clades are separated by tens to hundreds of thousands of SNPs. Molecular epidemiologic analyses revealed that WGS supports a simultaneous and independent emergence of C. auris in four global regions (194). By utilizing WGS and epidemiologic data, public health investigators can track the spread of C. auris globally, as well as identify new introductions in specific regions or in health care settings (195).

sect2.title: Sustained Transmission in Areas that Are Destined for Elimination
sect2.para: Molecular surveillance for viral diseases that are prevented by vaccination is especially beneficial when it is possible to observe the change in viral genotypes over time in a particular country or region. This information, when analyzed in conjunction with standard epidemiologic data, has helped to document the interruption of transmission of endemic viruses and provides a means to measure the success of vaccination programs.

Molecular characterization of measles viruses has provided a valuable tool for measuring the effectiveness of measles control programs. In general, three patterns of measles genotype distribution have been described. In countries that still have endemic transmission of measles, the majority of cases are caused by several endemic genotypes that are distributed geographically. In these cases, multiple cocirculating lineages within the endemic genotype or genotypes are present. In countries that have eliminated measles, the small numbers of cases are caused by a number of different genotypes that reflect various sources of imported virus and suggest the lack of sustained transmission of an endemic genotype or genotypes. The third pattern occurs in countries or regions that have had very good measles control but are experiencing an increase in the numbers of susceptible individuals because of failure to maintain high rates of vaccination coverage. In this situation, reintroduction of measles usually results in a large outbreak associated with a single genotype of virus with nearly identical sequences (160, 196).

sect2.title: Emerging Infection and Zoonosis Investigation
sect2.para: Molecular methods are crucial for the discovery of new pathogens, especially viral pathogens, and to determine whether a pathogen is truly new or has arisen from known pathogens through recombination or other genetic events. For example, coronaviruses have the ability to recombine with other coronaviruses as well as to incorporate cellular genes into their genomes (197). The initial analysis of the complete genome sequence of the coronavirus associated with severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS-CoV) confirmed that the virus was a novel coronavirus and not a recombinant between previously described coronaviruses. In 2012, rapid WGS of a novel coronavirus causing acute respiratory syndrome in humans (HCoV-EMC or MERS-CoV) showed that the new virus was a new variant, betacoronavirus, that was closely related to a bat coronavirus and more distantly related to SARS-CoV (198–200). Similarly, studies of SARS-CoV-2, which first emerged in Hubei province, China, in late 2019, were important in understanding the evolution and emergence of the virus, the role of local wildlife and populations in epizoonotic spillover, and the features that contributed to transmission and pathogenesis (201).

Use of molecular epidemiology has greatly increased our understanding of the sources of many other emerging or reemerging pathogens, such as Zika virus (202) and Ebola virus (203). One of the best-known molecular epidemiologic studies is the report on HIV “patient zero,” which linked transmission of HIV-1 among a specific cluster of early North American AIDS cases (204). However, more recent analyses of archival full-genome sequences have since demonstrated evidence of earlier transmission events (205, 206).

Over a longer time scale, genetic information can be employed, in conjunction with other evidence, to identify the spillover events leading to zoonotic disease. Molecular epidemiologic studies have been used to understand the zoonotic events that have led to epidemics in the past 3 decades. Some examples include the origin of HIV-1 from a zoonosis of simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) in chimpanzees (207), the origin of HIV-2 from a zoonosis of SIV in sooty mangabeys (208, 209), fruit bats as reservoirs of Ebola virus (210), camels as reservoirs of MERS coronavirus (211), and avian and human genome reassortments leading to the 1918 H1N1, 1957 H2N2, and 1968 H3N2 influenza pandemics. The 2009 H1N1 “swine flu” virus was found to be a triple-reassortant swine virus that had genetic components from human, swine, and avian influenza virus strains (212).

sect2.title: 2019 SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19)
sect2.para: Since the first case of SARS-CoV-2 was identified in humans in late 2019, and within the first 2 years of the pandemic, more than 270 million confirmed cases were reported worldwide to the World Health Organization (WHO), with more than 5.3 million reported deaths (213, 214). This section includes some brief consideration of the role of genomic epidemiology and bioinformatics in the COVID-19 pandemic response. For a more detailed discussion, please turn to the newly revised Coronavirus chapter 93.

Genomic surveillance was scaled up rapidly in many countries and quickly became an important source of public health information for outbreak response, public health decision making, diagnostic, therapeutic, and vaccine monitoring, and risk assessment. In particular, epidemiologically significant sequence variants were identified using methods that represent the merging of legacy public health data systems with emergent data science technologies. Consensus amplicon protocols for sequencing were developed and widely adopted (215), and in many countries, consensus sequence data for viral isolates were shared through open sequence repositories such as EpiCoV at the Global Initiative for Sharing Avian Influenza Data (GISAID; https://www.epicov.org), Genbank at the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA; https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena), and the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI; https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov). By the end of 2021, over 6 million sequences had been shared through these open database platforms, enabling real-time global surveillance and international collaboration on emerging variants and ensuring that the transmission dynamics and genomic features of emerging SARS-CoV-2 viruses could be studied and assessed by researchers, public health, and policymakers from all over the world.

For countries implementing large-scale sequencing, the cost and complexity of genomic sequencing were often not the most critical rate-limiting step for implementation of variant surveillance. Reliable and representative sample acquisition often proved to be a bigger challenge, an issue that motivated implementation of the National SARS-CoV-2 Strain Surveillance (NS3) program in the United States, among other similar initiatives worldwide (213). Challenges inherent to large-scale bioinformatics activities such as this include information volume, along with the high complexity of integration between datasets covering genomic sequences, epidemiology, clinical outcomes, and other relevant contextual information. A number of countries mounted large sequencing consortia and worked together to standardize and improve sequencing and bioinformatic performance, to standardize metadata capture, labeling, and nomenclature, and to build shared bioinformatic platforms and infrastructure that could be adapted to a range of microbial surveillance needs (216, 217). Bioinformatics software and applications also evolved to meet the complex needs of the pandemic, with tools for large-scale simplified sequence analysis and variant classification, such as Pangolin (https://pango.network) and Nextclade (https://clades.nextstrain.org), and the widespread use of data integration tools and platforms such as MicroReact (http://www.microreact.org), Nextstrain (https://www.nextstrain.org) (Fig. 5), and Outbreak.info (https://outbreak.info) to enable the visualization, interpretation, and exploration of phylogenetic data in the context of epidemiology, place, and time (217–220). While the scale and speed of the sequencing response to the pandemic has been without precedent, it is all but certain that many of these advances and investments in real-time genomic surveillance will be applied to other pathogens of public health concern, both now and in the future.

sect2.title: SUBTYPING METHOD SELECTION, VALIDATION, AND DATA INTERPRETATION

sect1.title: Method Selection
sect1.para: All too often, it appears that the selection of subtyping methods has been guided only by convenience criteria, in particular the accessibility of a method to the laboratory. This has led to numerous studies in which an inappropriate method was used to study an organism (1). When selecting a subtyping method, one should first consider the epidemiological context in which it is going to be used (i.e., what is the question that the typing data should answer). A method that is appropriate for long-term surveillance may not be appropriate for a short-term investigation of a health care-related outbreak. Careful consideration should also be given to the genetic makeup of the target organisms, including the clonality, mode of transmission, and outbreak potential. In the near future, method selection might become less of an issue, because WGS, due to its universality and flexibility, likely will be used for almost all molecular epidemiological applications.

sect2.title: Factors that Impact the “Clonality” of a Given Population
sect2.para: The clonal relatedness of isolates is manifested by their display of significantly higher levels of similarity in their genotype and/or phenotype than can be expected from randomly sampled and epidemiologically unrelated isolates of the same species (1). The simplest explanation for a genetically monomorphic pathogen is that the population size of the ancestors of all extant organisms was so strongly reduced during a recent bottleneck that genetic diversity was abolished. One possibility that can result in such a bottleneck is a crucial genetic event that happened only once, such as a change in ecological niche due to the acquisition of two plasmids by the progenitor of Yersinia pestis (221). In the case of STEC O157, it has been suggested that clonality can be explained by source-sink evolution dynamics (222–224). According to this theory, mutations in microbes that reside mainly in reservoirs (the source, e.g., cattle) in which they are not pathogens confer on a small subset a phenotype that results in injury to an accidental host (the sink, e.g., humans). Alternatively, it has been argued that a strong selective advantage conferred by a mutation enabled certain strains of STEC O157 to flourish in cattle, making them more available for spillover into humans (224). On the other hand, some host-restricted pathogens, such as S. enterica serotype Typhi, are under relatively little selection pressure from their host or environment and therefore do not diversify through point mutations, recombination, or acquisition of new sequences (225). Finally, a sampling bias may also contribute to the appearance of population clonality. Sampling from one part of the phylogenetic tree will overlook much of the variation present in the population and collapse all isolates outside the studied population into a single type (226). If WGS is not available, subtyping methods targeting rapidly evolving genetic elements, such as VNTRs or SNPs, are usually preferred (227, 228) in order to be able to adequately discriminate clonal organisms. With some organisms, optimal results may be obtained by using multiple techniques (e.g., PFGE and VNTR analysis) (229).

sect1.title: Method Validation
sect1.para: Once a proper method or approach has been selected, it must be subjected to the closest scrutiny possible to ensure that it meets the criteria discussed at the beginning of this chapter. This includes validation using a population of strains and isolates that originate from the epidemiological context in which the method is going to be applied. Techniques that will be applied in local investigations need to be validated on a strain collection from the same locality, whereas methods that will be used for community-wide surveillance need to be validated on a collection of strains reflecting the diversity in the whole community. When a subtyping method that has been validated for use in one given epidemiological context is to be used in a different one, it may be necessary to validate it in the new context before it is implemented. This supplementing validation may not need to be as thorough as the original validation, depending on how similar the two contexts are.

Unlike methods developed in isolation (for use by one laboratory), methods to be used in multiple laboratories for the generation of data archived in reference libraries must be particularly carefully tested, evaluated, and validated. All methods need to go through four phases of validation: initial development, internal validation, external validation, and postimplementation evaluation. The first two phases often overlap. Additionally, before the new method is implemented, a quality assurance and quality control program needs to be established.

The goal of the initial development is to identify the optimal conditions or parameters to ensure that the protocol is robust and reproducible and that it generates highly discriminatory and epidemiologically concordant data on all strains. Ten to 50 isolates that represent the diversity in the study population at large are typically used in this phase.

During the internal validation, the method is tested by individuals not involved in the method development, in order to ascertain the robustness of the protocol in the hands of laboratorians with no prior experience with it. The panel of test isolates is expanded to include the full genetic diversity of the study population and should contain both sporadic and outbreak-related isolates in order to test the true discriminatory power and the epidemiological concordance of the method. Duplicate isolates of the same strain and multiple isolates from single-source outbreaks need to be included to evaluate the reproducibility and stability of the method. The test panel will usually contain 100 to 500 isolates. If a gold standard subtyping method already exists for the organism, it may be possible to use a collection of strains of known subtype to validate the new method and assess its performance against existing methods.

During the external validation, the robustness and portability of the method are further tested, typically by 5 to 10 external partner laboratories, ideally with different levels of subtyping expertise and access to different types or brands of equipment and reagents. The assay is evaluated using 10 to 50 isolates selected by the laboratory that developed the method. The interlaboratory reproducibility of the method is also assessed during this phase. Sometimes the external validation is further expanded to include prospective or retrospective testing of up to 50 isolates from each laboratory’s own collection.

Following the successful completion of these phases, the method may be implemented. However, even after its implementation, the performance of the assay needs to be assessed on a regular basis to detect problems not identified during the initial validation and to assess emerging situations, such as the impact of introduction of new brands of reagents or instrument platforms that may have become commercially available.

sect2.title: Laboratory Quality Assurance and Quality Control
sect2.para: A quality assurance program needs to be in place before any molecular subtyping technique is implemented, to ensure consistently high quality and reproducibility of the data generated. At a minimum, subtyping should be performed only by personnel trained in working with the procedure, and a written standard operating procedure should be in place. In order to detect procedural failures, quality control measures, such as quantification of the DNA template or DNA sequencing library and positive and negative control samples for assays involving PCR amplification, should be included in the routine workflow. For reference library subtyping systems involving a network of laboratories, participation in an external quality assessment (EQA) program that includes an initial certification and annual proficiency testing is mandatory. An EQA program should encompass both the laboratory and the data analysis procedures (230, 231).

Due to the tremendous amount of sequence data generated by NGS, which routinely generates billions of sequences per run, there is an inherent risk of sequence contamination. Despite the broad utility of NGS in pathogen detection, the technique can be prone to contamination from sample handling, laboratory procedures, reagent contamination, run-to-run contamination, and within-run barcode “bleed-over.” For example, some Illumina MiSeq platform users experiencing assay-to-assay contamination of sequence data can alleviate or completely resolve this issue by performing a hypochlorite line wash between sequence runs. In addition, sequencing high-titer targets along with low-titer targets in the same sequencing assay could cause bleed-over of reads from the former to the latter. Even laboratory reagents can be a source of contamination. A small DNA virus that was initially detected in hepatitis patients (232) was the result of contamination in the silica column used during nucleic acid extraction (233). In addition, some commercial RT preparations can harbor murine retrovirus RNA, likely originating from the manufacturing process (T. Ng, unpublished data).

Molecular techniques such as PCR that exponentially amplify nucleic acids can also be prone to contamination, especially if nested PCRs are performed. For example, murine leukemia viruses (MLVs), including xenotropic-MLV-related virus, were linked to chronic fatigue syndrome; however, these findings were subsequently refuted (234) based on overwhelming evidence that the initial result was generated by contamination of MLV sequences in commercial laboratory reagents (235).

To exclude laboratory-derived contamination when pure cultures are sequenced, run-to-run and within-run analyses should be routinely performed after NGS to identify potential contaminating sequences. Additionally, including positive and negative controls in metagenomics applications is recommended.

sect1.title: Data Interpretation
sect1.para: One of the cornerstones of molecular epidemiology is the assumption that the biological relatedness of microorganisms observed by subtyping reflects epidemiological relatedness. However, it is well known that this correlation is far from perfect, and for that reason, subtyping information can never stand alone. Whenever one is interpreting a biological subtyping “match,” it is critical to ask the question: how does this match fit with all other information available? One must consider the epidemiological context and other data, such as associated demographic and epidemiological information, as well as other subtyping information (e.g., biochemical reaction profiles, serotype, phage type, antimicrobial susceptibility profiles, and presence of virulence factors). Reliance on a single parameter for characterization should be avoided whenever possible. Knowledge about the subtyping method, including the quality of the data, diversity of the organism, and the history of the subtypes encountered, should also be considered (236).

sect2.title: Quality of the Data
sect2.para: Even when a carefully standardized procedure is followed, artifacts may occur which may lead to erroneous conclusions about relationships between profiles. It is therefore important to know the nature of these artifacts in order to recognize and correct them. In this, the role of the database curator is extremely important. In PFGE, the artifacts include, among other things, ghost bands caused by incomplete restriction and subtle differences in band resolution (one thick band versus two thinner bands) (236). In PCR-based methods, such as RAPD and rep-PCR, differences in band intensities are a huge problem, and in MLVA, PCR, and fragment analysis, artifacts such as minus A, stutter peaks, and fluorescence carryover can confuse data interpretation (237). Sanger sequence trace files should be routinely checked for quality either manually or using software (e.g., Phred/Phrap [http://www.phrap.org]). Most major sequence databases require the submission of the raw sequence trace files from the laboratory when a new allele type is proposed (238).

The quality of the next-generation WGS data can be assessed using various quality metrics that are based on the raw reads (e.g., per-base sequence quality, sequence length distribution, GC bias, and sequence coverage) or assemblies (e.g., U50,N50, number of contigs, and assembly length) and can be generated by using either the software built into the sequencing system or external software packages (118, 239). It is important to recognize that the quality of the genome assemblies reflects the quality of the sequencing technology used and also of the analysis software employed for assembly and annotation (240). For reference library systems involving multiple laboratories, it is crucial that all participants strictly adhere to mutually agreed-on thresholds, such as minimum sequence coverage and quality scores; otherwise, downstream analyses can be compromised (241, 242). The quality and integrity of downstream analyses can be further evaluated by monitoring the reference genome alignment in the high-quality SNP (hqSNP) analysis and the number of alleles called in the wgMLST analysis (230). Many of the parameters mentioned above can also give important clues about possible sequence contamination, underscoring the need to include appropriate controls, including negative controls, and reference samples of known type and characteristics.

sect3.title: Bioinformatics and Reporting Standards
sect3.para: Quality management strategies for molecular epidemiology have become increasingly complex, particularly with the advent of routine pathogen genomics and proteomics assays in public health and clinical microbiology. While the process of documenting protocols, performance measures, controls, and competency assessment for laboratory-based components of these protocols is generally well understood, these assays also require significant bioinformatic infrastructure and workforce expertise, customized open-source and/or proprietary software analysis pipelines, and access to high-performance computing resources, data management, and specialized reference databases that make quality management frameworks far more complicated to implement and maintain. Recently, a number of different expert workgroups have been established to help define quality management systems in the context of NGS-based surveillance and reference testing and the implications for regulatory and laboratory accreditation. Many of the basic recommendations and requirements are generalizable between laboratories and can be readily adapted to different pathogen testing and analysis workflows, making these discussions an important first step in implementing reproducible genomic methods and best practices for a wide range of public health laboratory applications and routine use cases (243–246). In the United States, a growing number of public health laboratories are beginning to transition to NGS-based assays under Clinical Laboratory Improvements Act (CLIA) accreditation (230). As NGS becomes more prominent as a reference testing strategy, this is certain to be an important consideration for many laboratories. Expert groups have also put together strong sets of recommendations on the reporting of molecular epidemiologic studies and results, such as the Strengthening the Reporting of Molecular Epidemiology for Infectious Diseases (STROME-ID) statement (247) and STROBE-metagenomics for reporting of complex metagenomic datasets and findings (248).

sect2.title: Diversity of the Organism
sect2.para: Optimal interpretation of the differences (or lack thereof) between subtypes of two isolates depends largely on the variability of the organism being typed. Large databases should provide sufficient data to make reasonable determinations of diversity. If an organism displays little diversity, one should be cautious in assuming that closely related patterns, or even indistinguishable patterns, indicate a high likelihood that they originate from a common source. In this case, additional data from other typing methods and other available information should be considered. If the organism shows substantial diversity, one must still consider whether there are clonal subpopulations within a nonclonal organism. On the other hand, when an organism demonstrates extreme variability, any pattern matches may be significant.

sect2.title: Epidemiological Context
sect2.para: If the epidemiological setting from which the isolates are derived appears to be a point source outbreak without continued transmission, only very minor differences are likely to be observed, because the outbreak strain has very little time to undergo genetic changes. In contrast, when there is ongoing transmission—such as prolonged hospital or community outbreaks, with strains being passed from person to person, or zoonotic outbreaks, with strains being passed from animal to animal before spilling over to humans—more variability should be expected. Additionally, the amount of variation seen during an outbreak will depend on the stability of the genetic markers targeted by the typing method. Fast-evolving genetic markers, such as VNTRs, tend to change slightly even during shorter outbreaks (58). During investigations of known outbreaks, it is fairly easy and often helpful to designate patterns that differ slightly from the primary outbreak pattern as subpatterns or variants. However, during surveillance for cluster or outbreak detection, accepting such variations may mislead the epidemiological investigation (249), especially if one of the variants represents a common pattern.

It is also important to consider how the laboratory results fit together with the epidemiologic and environmental investigations. The fact that common subtypes exist for many organisms demonstrates that indistinguishable subtypes alone do not unequivocally prove an epidemiologic connection. It is always possible that two individuals were infected with the same strain from different sources. On the other hand, clearly differing subtypes do not prove that isolates are epidemiologically unrelated, since multiple strains can be associated with the same outbreak (250) and some strains contain genetic elements (e.g., prophages) which are incorporated in the genome in an unstable manner and therefore may affect the subtype of different colonies picked from the same pure culture of the organism (251). For this reason, when high-resolution subtyping methods such as hqSNP analysis are used, it is advisable to exclude mobile genetic elements and repeat regions from the analysis, because they may introduce phylogenetic noise into the investigation (252). With analysis methods that utilize WGS data, such as hqSNP and wgMLST, setting thresholds for relatedness is not always straightforward, and utilizing a hierarchical method for cluster detection may be beneficial (105, 253, 254).

sect2.title: LIBRARIES FOR MOLECULAR EPIDEMIOLOGY
sect2.para: International travel, migration, and food trade are the main factors that have contributed to the worldwide spread of microbes. Therefore, the need for international databases with standardized type nomenclature and information on epidemiologically relevant strains has emerged. Building such databases relies upon standardization of typing methods and on regular EQA trials for all participating laboratories to guarantee consistently comparable data.

sect1.title: Strain Catalogues and Sequence Repositories
sect1.para: Strain catalogue databases are mainly public access websites with limited access components in some of them. Their main function is to standardize subtype nomenclature and facilitate easy data sharing. Most of them are curated but typically contain minimal epidemiological or demographic information about the strains and are therefore not always useful for real-time epidemiological surveillance. The laboratories that contribute data to strain catalogues use protocols that vary in the level of standardization, from none (MLVA) to medium (spa typing).

Some of the best-known examples of strain libraries are the MLST databases that are hosted on Web servers located at Oxford University (http://pubmlst.org) and L’Institut Pasteur (https://bigsdb.pasteur.fr) (238,255,256). On the Oxford and Institut Pasteur websites, species-specific information, including limited epidemiological data, can be accessed on each of the species websites, whereas pubmlst.org software enables multiple client databases to query a single species-specific profiles database, so that the information on isolates can be kept private for security or confidentiality reasons. Each species-specific database holds the sequences of all known alleles at each of the MLST loci and, through the curator, assigns new allele numbers and sequence types. The websites also provide clustering tools to explore the relationship of the query strain with other strains in the database, and have recently been expanded to support BIGSdb core genome MLST.

SeqNet (http://www.seqnet.org/), coordinated by the Münster University Hospital and Robert Koch Institute in Wernigerode, Germany, is an example of a non-MLST-based strain catalogue. SeqNet is an initiative of 60 national reference laboratories and university laboratories from 29 European countries to establish a network of sequence-based typing of microbial pathogens (257). However, it has been unable to expand to additional organisms. The only database SeqNet has hosted since its inception is the curated spa-server for S. aureus spa types.

International databases for MLVA data were established about a decade ago. The only notable one still surviving at this time is the MLVAbank (https://microbesgenotyping.i2bc.paris-saclay.fr/), hosted by the Université Paris Sud, Orsay, France. MLVAbank has both public and private databases available for a few organisms (63). The public databases have been derived from published data, sometimes by merging publications from different groups. Since the VNTR markers used by different groups are not always the same because of the current lack of standardization, different data sets may be available for different sets of isolates. Because different sets of primers are sometimes used for the same marker by different groups and because there are sizing discrepancies between different capillary electrophoresis platforms, the data are not always directly comparable, even though they are uploaded to MLVAbank as repeat copy numbers.

The GenomeTrakr database, housed on the NCBI website, contains raw sequence data and metadata on isolate source and geographic origin for food and environmental strains ofSalmonella, Listeria, E. coli, Shigella, and Campylobacter. The purpose of the database is to serve as an attribution database against which prospective food and environmental isolates can be compared during outbreak investigations, to provide clues on the possible origin of the strain of interest (259). Participants of the U.S.-based GenomeTrakr network include state, federal, academic, and commercial laboratories and some international partners. The network is governed by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration and has partnered with NCBI Pathogen Detection Pipeline for centralized daily hqSNP analysis of data (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pathogens/) (260).

sect1.title: Public Health Surveillance Databases
sect1.para: Surveillance databases are restricted-access curated databases for real-time sharing of subtyping data and detailed demographic information associated with the strains. The main function of surveillance databases is to rapidly detect and define clusters of disease in order to initiate and support epidemiological investigations that are aimed at tracing the source and limiting the scope of outbreaks. Laboratories contributing data to surveillance databases typically are required to follow highly standardized protocols and comply with an extensive quality assurance/quality control program to ensure the reproducibility and the high quality of data.

PulseNet, the national and international surveillance network for foodborne disease, is the most successful example of a surveillance database. PulseNet USA was established in 1996 (23), and similar networks later followed in Canada, the Asia Pacific region, Latin America, the Middle East, and Europe, and most recently in Africa (261) (https://pulsenetinternational.org). Historically, participating PulseNet laboratories performed standardized PFGE protocols on all foodborne bacterial isolates obtained from clinical, food, and environmental specimens. PFGE gel patterns were then analyzed locally using highly customized software and uploaded to the central databases for each region via the Internet. There, database managers confirmed the quality of the patterns, named them according to a standardized naming convention, and compared them against the patterns submitted to the database within the previous 60 days (or 120 days for Listeria).

Starting in 2018, most PulseNet USA and PulseNet International laboratories began to transition to genomic sequence-based analysis, with most labs completing the transition by 2019. As before, participating laboratories perform WGS on all foodborne organisms they receive from clinical, food, and environmental specimens in real time. The WGS data are analyzed on a local computer cluster or in the cloud, where they are evaluated for quality, reassembled and annotated from raw reads, and subjected to a series of organism-specific analyses, including allele calling for core genome MLST. A single linkage tree is generated from the cgMLST data, and a hierarchical name, called an allele code, is assigned. Isolates that are closely genetically related share multiple digits of the allele code (25). The epidemiologists are alerted if a new cluster of closely genetically related isolates is detected. Until now, much of the work in PulseNet International has focused on establishing the infrastructure of the network, but eventually each regional network will be able to log on to the server of any other international network, query the databases for matches to pathogen subtypes of interest, and, if matches are found, access the epidemiologic information on matching isolate patterns (261). Such collaboration is already taking place between PulseNet USA and PulseNet Canada. PulseNet International is in the process of replacing traditional reference characterization methods, such as serotyping, virulence and antibiotic resistance profiling, and PFGE subtyping, with WGS. Their vision is to use standardized cgMLST methods to extract reference and subtyping information from the sequences utilizing curated allele and strain nomenclature databases housed in the public domain (112). PulseNet USA has also committed to releasing the raw sequence data with very limited metadata on the NCBI website in real time. The analyzed data and the more detailed metadata will still be housed in the restricted-access databases.

Other PulseNet-like surveillance databases include the CaliciNet network in the United States (262) and the Foodborne Viruses in Europe network (263), which deals mainly with norovirus. The virological networks primarily employ DNA sequence analysis. A number of virus-specific, curated databases, such as MeaNS for measles virus and RubeNS for rubella virus (264) and GISAID for influenza and SARS-CoV-2 (265), have been established. These databases can usually be identified by an Internet search and are often open to new registrants, but may impose some level of usage restrictions to protect the rights of submitting laboratories. For a number of other viruses, public health and academic laboratories often deposit sequence data directly to public databases such as Genbank, where they may be linked to other data sources and used for secondary analysis and discovery with fewer limitations (266).

sect2.title: CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE TRENDS
sect2.para: Molecular methods have improved our understanding of the epidemiology of infectious diseases and the well-known emerging or reemerging pathogens causing them during the past 4 decades. Molecular methods have been used not only to subtype and otherwise characterize the pathogens following their culture but also to identify and detect nonculturable or slowly growing organisms (267–269). The emergence and increased use of a plethora of culture-independent diagnostic tests (270, 271) in the clinical laboratories in the past few years have resulted in decreased availability of cultures for further characterization in public health laboratories. This trend may place culture-dependent surveillance networks such as PulseNet in serious jeopardy (272). However, with the rapid evolution of NGS technologies, including metagenomics (273), it is to be expected that these methods will be used to an increasing extent for rapid non-culture-based diagnostics of infectious diseases directly from a clinical sample, providing detection, virulence characterization, and subtyping of the organisms at the same time, thereby creating the potential for detection of public health events (e.g., outbreaks) in real time, with no delays caused by isolating and growing the organisms as pure cultures (274, 275). Before this can be accomplished, some formidable challenges need to be tackled, such as building comprehensive sequence reference libraries for metagenomics, containing a representative diversity not only of pathogenic microbes but also of the human microbiome (276, 277). Public health informatics constitutes another challenge, as does ensuring that the users of the data are alerted to and know how to use the growing information flowing from clinical laboratories.
